poem:
"Of Payments and Progress"

Kerr-ching, it hums,
the tired metaphor,
not the simple store bell's ping,
but a whirlwind symphony 
of clicks and taps,
web-strung, silken whispers,
extending their coded touch.
Invisible hand interposes -
transaction transposed,
from tactile to digital − 
complexity cloaked as simplicity.
Oh the music of commerce,
unseen, unheard,
but in the pulse of progress,
yet how tangible,
the taste of success.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "From security to coverage: seven things sellers need to know about payments “Kerr-ching” – the sound of an old-fashioned cash register symbolises that magic moment when a customer taps, swipes, clicks or phones in a transaction and a sale is made. But with an ever-expanding roll of payment methods for online, mobile and physical storefronts, and an intricate web of software systems involved, the process behind that metaphorical sound of success gets more complex by". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
